items.title: Support class method handlers (was: Let me join the discussion.)
items.body:
Let me join the discussion.
I see the issue with using class methods with TinyRPC.
Example code:
```
dispatch = RPCDispatcher()

class Baz(object):

    @dispatch.public(name='do_something')
    def visible_method(arg1)
        # ...
```
The problem here is that visible_method cannot have access to class instance.
If it is declared as:
```
def visible_method(self, arg1):
    ...
```
note adding self as 1-st argument so this method cannot be called.
By default I get *JSONRPCError: Invalid params*, if I set *dispatch.validator = None* I get *missing 1 required positional argument*.

I like TinyRPC for it's flexibility and I was using caller arg in previous versions to inject class instance.
But anyway it was a hack and I think we should have a nice support for class instances.

Thanks.

_Originally posted by @litnimax in https://github.com/mbr/tinyrpc/issues/74#issuecomment-500687085_

Thanks!

items.title: JSONRPCProtocol._caller fails with built-in functions

milestone.title: v1.0
milestone.description:
New major version due to incompatible changes.
However main focus is on documentation and tests.

items.body:
Hello,

I am using tinyrpc in a project.
In tinyrpc.protocols.jsonrpc.JSONRPCProtocol#_caller, if the argument `method` is a built-in function, a `TypeError: unsupported callable` error is raised, so tinyrpc raises a `JSONRPCInvalidParamsError`. I believe it should not.

My use case is to use tinyrpc in order to remotely control a PyQt GUI. Being able to control PyQt built-ins would make my work a lot easier.
If there is any reason for this behavior to be desired, please let me know.

Thank you.

items.title: Make import geventwebsocket conditional
items.body:
In `tinyrpc/transports/http.py:6` is a hard unconditional import for `geventwebsocket`. This makes python fail when `geventwebsocket` is not installed.

When you comment line `tinyrpc/transports/http.py:6` the HTTP variant of the client works fine. Could you add a import condition for `geventwebsocket` to only import the module if this is installed? (exception?)

Suppose you can, can you release this change for both python2 and python3?

items.title: Modify client error handling

milestone.title: v1.0
milestone.description:
New major version due to incompatible changes.
However main focus is on documentation and tests.

items.body:
RPCClient._send_and_handle_reply() raises an RPCError based on the contents of the error attribute in the reply message. However the contents of the error reply are not preserved.

Change RPCClient and RPCError so that RPCError contains the error, message and data attributes of the error reply.

Also allow RPCError to correctly propagates through a chain of services.

items.title: TypeError: bytes expected
items.body:
We have been using tinryrpc since version 0.6 .
Our code (which is very similar to the http_server_example.py) fails in version 0.7 and above with the following traceback:

```
 Fri Jun  1 08:12:21 2018 <Greenlet at 0x7f011de5c2a8: handle_message(<Queue at 0x7f011de054e0 getters[1]>, b'{"jsonrpc": "2.0", "id": 1, "method": "get_activ)> failed with TypeError
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/dist-packages/gevent/greenlet.py", line 536, in run 
    result = self._run(*self.args, **self.kwargs)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/dist-packages/tinyrpc/server/__init__.py", line 90, in handle_message
    self.transport.send_reply(context, result)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/dist-packages/tinyrpc/transports/wsgi.py", line 52, in send_reply
    raise TypeError('bytes expected')
TypeError: bytes expected
```
We reproduced the above both in a Debian8 and a Debian9 environment.
lib versions:

- tinyrpc==0.9.1
- gevent==1.2.2
- greenlet==0.4.13
- MarkupSafe==1.0
- requests==2.4.3
- six==1.11.0
- Werkzeug==0.14.1


At your disposal for further tests or information

The use of strings in handling and as function parameters is underspecified and inconsistent.

items.title: JSONRPCProtocol.parse_request fails on string values
items.body:
https://github.com/mbr/tinyrpc/blob/6fb5aaa88c1e1afb7643560b8d133dcc970a58a3/tinyrpc/protocols/jsonrpc.py#L289-L304

The 'parse_request' method implementation of the JSONRPCProtocol class does not check whether the request is a string(which should probably generate a 'JSONRPCInvalidRequestError'), and then tries to treat the parsed value as a mapping, which will raise an attribute error if the value is a string(`'str' object has no attribute 'keys'`). 

The solution should be to check if the value is not a dict(or a mapping) after checking if it's a list, and raising a `JSONRPCInvalidRequestError` in that case.

items.title: Review handling of id

milestone.title: v1.0
milestone.description:
New major version due to incompatible changes.
However main focus is on documentation and tests.

items.body:
The way the server responds to an absent id in a request as well as it having the value null should
be reviewed.

While at it also check correct processing of error responses.
[JSON-RPC forum](https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/json-rpc/a5tApN2Vn-c) suggests
that an error should be produced as long as it is not certain that a request is a notification.
This would mean that as soon as the json string is successfully parsed and the absence of the id field is established no error responses should be sent.

| Option | Needed to use objects of class |
|:-----------:|:---------------------:|
| httpclient | HttpPostClientTransport, HttpWebSocketClientTransport | 

So I installed `tinyrpc` with dependencies for the httpclient as follows.
```
(venv-httpclient) $ pip install tinyrpc[httpclient]
Successfully installed certifi-2017.7.27.1 chardet-3.0.4 idna-2.6 requests-2.18.4 six-1.11.0 tinyrpc-0.6 urllib3-1.22 websocket-client-0.44.0
```
However, I cannot import `HttpPostClientTransport` and `HttpWebSocketClientTransport`.

```python
In [1]: from tinyrpc.transports.http import HttpPostClientTransport
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ModuleNotFoundError                       Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-1-3163bebc390b> in <module>()
----> 1 from tinyrpc.transports.http import HttpPostClientTransport

/home/penguin/venv-httpclient/lib/python3.6/site-packages/tinyrpc/transports/http.py in <module>()
      3 
      4 import requests
----> 5 import geventwebsocket as websocket
      6 
      7 from . import ClientTransport

In [2]: from tinyrpc.transports.http import HttpWebSocketClientTransport
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
```

items.title: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'serialize' when Id is zero or unspecified
items.body:
Hi 

I am a newbie on the python so please bare with me if the analysis is not accurately enough.

We have seen that when a json request is sent, where either the id is omitted or alternatively the id is set to the number 0 the following error is experienced:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "src\test\python\plugins\TestPlugin.py", line 80, in <module>
    rpc_server.serve_forever()
  File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\tinyrpc\server__init__.py", line 56, in serve_forever
    self._spawn(handle_message, context, message)
  File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\tinyrpc\server__init__.py", line 71, in _spawn
    func(_args, *_kwargs)
  File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\tinyrpc\server__init__.py", line 54, in handle_message
    self.transport.send_reply(context, response.serialize())
AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'serialize'

The reason for this is is that the RPCServer in tinyrpc/server/**init**.py (line 57) has logic that assumes that it has a serialize method:

```
        # send reply
        self.transport.send_reply(context, response.serialize())
```

The reason why the serialize is not available is due to the JSONRpcRequest in the file tinyrpc/protocols/jsonrpc.py(lines 110-111 and lines 125-126):

```
    if not self.unique_id:
        return None
```

I was wondering wouldn't it be more appropriate either to raise an exception, set an arbitrary id or alternatively return an object, which has serialize on it.

br

Meang

Because with a fast enough server, the number of sockets available will run out quickly.

However, I don't see how JSON-RPC 2.0 [_notification_](http://www.jsonrpc.org/specification#notification) can be done, i.e. Request object without an "id" member, which have no associated Response.

items.title: Error object's data attribute is dropped
items.body: According to the [spec](http://www.jsonrpc.org/specification#error_object), the error object may provide a data attribute. This is dropped in `parse_reply`. It should be preserved if present.

items.title: Incorrect error code if method is called with wrong number of arguments
Multiprocessing RPC
items.body:
Not so much an issue as a general point of discussion:

I have been thinking about how to do inter-process communication in python elegantly for a while, and the (tiny)RPC model looks really elegant compared to the typical ad-hoc queue mess.

Relative to what tinyrpc offers, I have written a pickle-based communication layer (to more easily facilitate numpy arrays or other python-specific datastructures; we don't need the language-neutrality of JSON for IPC), and a gevent.stream.StreamServer based transport layer, as zmq is overkill for this I would argue; plus StreamServer routes messages in a one-socket-per-greenlet style natively, which has to be emulated in zmq.

So far I havnt quite been able to hammer this approach into the tinyRPC design; specifically, it appears the RPCServer base class is somewhat tied to the zmq transport layer, with its context,message tuples. As such, integrating such a different transport layer in a natural way would require some changes to the existing architecture it seems.

What I have put together works really well for me, and I cant imagine doing inter-process communication the old way anymore. As far as I can tell, no such out of the box solutions exist as of yet, so itd be a nice addition to tinyrpc I think. So my questions are:
- Am I reinventing the wheel?
- If not, is this a wheel that deserves to be invented properly for others to use?
- Am I correct that this would require some minor changes to existing tinyrpc components?
- Is tinyrpc the right place to implement such functionality?

items.title: support for python3
items.body:
Hi Marc,
do you have plans to port tinyrpc to python3? among your transport layers, at least zmq supports python3 now. Or can you see any reason why porting shouldn't be possible?
Cheers
Adrian

items.title: Polling cycles for ZMQ Server
items.body:
Hi Marc,

Your Tinyrpc is amazing! Please consider the feature shown below for inclusion in your package. Adding polling cycles is needed if your server is going to do continuous tasks. 

Thanks,
Mark

``` python
# Add the polling option to the transport
class ZmqServerTransport(ServerTransport):
    """Server transport based on a :py:const:`zmq.ROUTER` socket.

    :param socket: A :py:const:`zmq.ROUTER` socket instance, bound to an
                   endpoint.
    """

    def __init__(self, socket, polling_milliseconds=0):
        self.socket = socket
        self.poller = None
        if polling_milliseconds:
            self.poller = zmq.Poller()
            self.poller.register(self.socket, zmq.POLLIN)
            self.polling_milliseconds = polling_milliseconds

    def receive_message(self):
        if self.poller:
            events = self.poller.poll(self.polling_milliseconds)
            if not len(events):
                return 0,0
        msg = self.socket.recv_multipart()
        return msg[:-1], msg[-1]

    def send_reply(self, context, reply):
        self.socket.send_multipart(context + [reply])

    @classmethod
    def create(cls, zmq_context, endpoint, polling_milliseconds=0):
        """Create new server transport.

        Instead of creating the socket yourself, you can call this function and
        merely pass the :py:class:`zmq.core.context.Context` instance.

        By passing a context imported from :py:mod:`zmq.green`, you can use
        green (gevent) 0mq sockets as well.

        :param zmq_context: A 0mq context.
        :param endpoint: The endpoint clients will connect to.
        """
        socket = zmq_context.socket(zmq.ROUTER)
        socket.bind(endpoint)
        return cls(socket, polling_milliseconds)

# Open RPC
server_port = 5001
polling_milliseconds = 1000
ctx = zmq.Context()
dispatcher = RPCDispatcher()
transport = ZmqServerTransport.create(ctx,
   'tcp://127.0.0.1:%d'%(server_port), polling_milliseconds)

rpc_server = RPCServer(
    transport,
    JSONRPCProtocol(),
    dispatcher
)

# The loop now has a process_polling() function:
while True:
    context = message = 0
    while not context and not message:
        context, message = rpc_server.transport.receive_message()
        if not context and not message:
            process_polling()

    # assuming protocol is threadsafe and dispatcher is theadsafe, as
    # long as its immutable

    def handle_message(context, message):
        try:
            request = rpc_server.protocol.parse_request(message)
        except RPCError as e:
            response = e.error_respond()
        else:
            response = rpc_server.dispatcher.dispatch(request)

        # send reply
        rpc_server.transport.send_reply(context, response.serialize())

    rpc_server._spawn(handle_message, context, message)
```

items.title: Docs about non blocking ClientTransport
items.body:
I think the current API exposed by tinyrpc ClientTransport is not well suited for non blocking environments like twisted, pulsar or tornado.

That is the current ClientTransport in tinyrpc:

```
class ClientTransport(object):
    """Base class for all client transports."""

    def send_message(self, message, expect_reply=True):
        """Send a message to the server and possibly receive a reply.

        Sends a message to the connected server.

        Messages must be strings, it is up to the sender to convert the
        beforehand. A non-string value raises a :py:exc:`TypeError`.

        This function will block until one reply has been received.

        :param message: A string to send.
        :return: A string containing the server reply.
        """
        raise NotImplementedError
```

A non-blocking client needs to accept two arguments:

success_callback and exception_callback.

Or the send_message() returns a deferred object ...

I think the issue should be resolved in two steps:
1. Document the ClientTransport: Not suited for non blocking environments.
2. Create a different API for non blocking clients.

items.title: Complete support for websockets
items.body:
Hi, I am trying to implement a version of websockets support on the lib that will need some extra hacking on the plumbing and I thought of asking the author @mbr what input he can give me so that it can be contributed back on a near future.

The implementations of WebSocket I've seen contributed use the socket either as a client or as a server but never as both. In my case, I need to use the same socket as a client and as a server and therefore I need to keep track of requests being sent and the responses being gotten out of order. For that, the most important part is that I need to store my requests unique_ids somewhere before actually using it.

Also, I would need to implement 2 transports. 1 that acts as a websockets client (I thought of using websocket-client for that) and other as a server (thought of using gevent-websocket).

So, the transport is quite easy, but I am unsure how I would go about implementing a server and a client all in the same and keep track of the requests unique_ids in the middle. First problem that appears is that I need to know what is a request and what is a response when a new message is received on the socket. I can do a loads on it and check for the existence of the result but I am guessing that would be very ineficient as it would be parsed again when it actually becomes a request or response.

What's is your input? Is there any interest on such a contribution?

items.title: Do you have a license ?
items.body:
Hi, this is exactly what i was looking for, we are implementing and JSONRPC overt WebSocket in flask with gevent, but.... i take a quick look to your code and can't found a license.

In absense of a license your work is All rights reserved, so no one can use it without your explicit permission.

If this is your intention, so i am asking for your permission, if not please consider license with a A-GPLv3 compatible license.

Thank you,
